Tabu {{small|(2001-10)}} | alternate_names = | status = | building_type = [[Theater (building)|Theater]] | architectural_style = [[Commercial style|Commercial]], [[Art Deco]] and [[Mediterranean Revival]] | address = 46 N Orange Ave
[[Orlando, Florida|Orlando, FL]] 32801-2419 | location_city = | location_country = | current_tenants = | start_date = | completion_date = December 9, 1921 | seating_capacity = 1,250 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 1936, 1953, 1976, 1981, 1984, 1988, 1992, 2000 | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | diameter = | floor_count = | floor_area = {{convert|30,965 |sqfoot}} | client = [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr. | owner = Beacham Theatre, LLC. (Missy Casscells and Frank Hamby) | other_dimensions = {{convert|145|ft}} across x {{convert|213.5|ft}} deep | architect = | architecture_firm = | main_contractor = | structural_system = Reinforced concrete and brick with stucco out-surface | coordinates = | map_type = | map_size = | embedded = | url = {{URL|http://www.thebeacham.com/|Venue Website}} }} The '''Beacham Theatre''' is a [[Cinema (building)|cinema]] built in 1921 by [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr. in the city of [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]]. The current address of the theater is 46 North Orange Avenue, and it is located at the southwest corner of Orange Avenue and Washington Street. The building's current lack of impressive [[architecture]] is offset by its significant [[cultural history]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-02-28/news/0020190106_1_tampa-theatre-beacham-theater-in-atlanta |title=Conflict Now Playing At Beacham Owner: Destroy It -- Activists: Save It |last1= Dezern |first1=Craig |date=February 28, 1988 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 11, 2016 |quote=But when preservationists look, they see a landmark. Square columns adorned with feathered capitals climb gracefully to a high ceiling decorated with rectangles of intricate plasterwork. An orchestra pit and the gentle slope of the auditorium floor wait, covered by modern alterations. The debate between progress and preservation has played in old theaters throughout the South, and sometimes preservation has won. But for every theater saved, two more meet the wrecking ball. The Beacham soon may join the fallen theaters. Juarez, a developer and political consultant, has applied for permission to tear down the building at 46 N. Orange Ave., and the Beacham lacks key elements that saved movie palaces in Tampa, Atlanta and Lakeland. Impressive architecture is one of those elements.}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-02-10/news/0010430175_1_historic-building-city-council-juarez |title=Beacham: The End Or A Full New Show? |last1= Blumenstyk |first1=Goldie|date=February 10, 1988|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 11, 2016|quote=}}{{Cite journal|last=Wilkening|first=David|date=February 1988|title=Can they save the Beacham?|url=|journal=Orlando Magazine|publisher=Orlando Magazine|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=City of Orlando Historic Preservation, Beacham File}} The Beacham Theatre was considered an important contributing structure when the [[Downtown Orlando]] [[historic district]] was created in 1980 and the building was granted local [[landmark]] status in 1987."The Beacham Theatre," City of Orlando, Historic Preservation Board The Beacham was once part of the [[vaudeville]] circuit and hosted celebrity acts such as [[John Phillip Sousa]], the [[Ziegfeld Follies]] and [[W.C. Fields]], whose signature was once visible inside a dressing room. In the eras of [[silent film]] and [[Classical Hollywood cinema#Classical Hollywood cinema In the Sound Era (late 1920s – 1960)|Classical Hollywood cinema]], the Beacham was operated as a [[movie theater]] that utilized then-current [[state-of-the-art]] [[Film|motion picture]] technology. '''The Beacham''', as it is currently named, has since been used as a series of [[concert venue]]s and [[nightclub]]s thus saving it from [[demolition]]. The Beacham Theatre was once home to the late-night [[Underground culture|underground]] [[discotheque]] '''Aahz''' that is recognized internationally as a birthplace and critical component of the [[electronic dance music]] [[Clubbing (subculture)|movement]]. ==History== ===Construction=== [[file:Orange_County_Florida_Jail_(gaol)_photo.jpg|thumb|165px|left|The former Orange County Jail on the site of the Beacham Theatre]] The Beacham Theatre was constructed in 1921 by [[Braxton Beacham]] Sr., who had previously owned three other Orlando theaters{{cite magazine |author= |title=With "News" Correspondents (Florida) |url=https://archive.org/stream/motionpicturenew23moti_7#page/3198/mode/2up |magazine=Motion Picture News|location=New York|publisher=Motion Picture News, Inc. |date=May–June 1921 |access-date=February 17, 2017 }} and had served as [[Mayor of Orlando]] during 1907. In 1917 Beacham paid approximately $17,500–$20,000 for the property one block southwest of his stately residence on Jefferson Street after Orlando's citizens voted to pave the road to the [[cemetery]] instead of purchasing the old jail. The property he purchased had formerly served as the [[gaol|jail]] for [[Orange County, Florida|Orange County]] since about 1873.{{cite book|author1=Stephanie Gaub Antequino|author2=Tana Mosier Porter|author3=Historical Society of Central Florida|title=Lost Orlando|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4xWDRXbzXsMC|year=2012|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-9173-5}} With a $200,000 investment, the former jail building was torn down in 1919 and Beacham developed a series of connected building units along the west side of Orange Avenue between Washington Street and Oak Street (now Wall Street). The new building was then known as "Beacham's Block" and is now known the Beacham Building. The location of Beacham's theater was precisely where several [[Capital punishment|condemned]] prisoners were executed by [[hanging]].{{cite magazine|last=Schaal Hinson|first=Sandra|date=February 1983|title=A mover behind shakers|url=|magazine=Orlando Magazine|location=Orlando|publisher=Orlando Magazine|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Beacham Has Come Long Way: Lillian Gish to Queen Esther|last=Ives|first=Sidney|date=December 23, 1953|work=The Orlando Evening Star|access-date=|via=}}{{cite news |url= |title= Curtain rises on new act for Beacham|last1=Sweers |first1=Katheryn |date=July 12, 1981 |website= |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date= |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-01-28/news/9601250598_1_orlando-opera-opera-house-movie-houses |title= Early Entertainment Venues Evolved From Opera House To Movie Theaters|last1=Andrews|first1=Mark|date=January 28, 1996 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date= August 21, 2016|quote=...the former site of the county jail where hangings once were conducted - and built the Beacham Theater...Air conditioning was installed in the '30s...It later was home to Laser World; then to Moulin Orange, a Las Vegas-style cabaret that lasted four months in 1983-84; and then to Valentyne's Celebrity Dinner Theatre, which opened in 1987.}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Requiem for the Beacham Theatre|last=Means|first=Howard|date=October 17, 1982|work=The Orlando Sentinel|access-date=|via=}} According to local [[folklore]], the Beacham Building is reportedly [[ghost|haunted]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2001-02-16/entertainment/0102150519_1_gavin-tour-downtown-orlando |title=A Jaunt Into Haunts |last1= Wallace Dickinson |first1= Joy |date=February 16, 2001 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= ''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date= August 14, 2016|quote=Gavin's tour includes tales of a sensational murder across the street from the Angebilt in the vanished San Juan Hotel and of a secret tunnel connecting the Angebilt to the old Beacham Theater (now the Tabu night spot at 46 N. Orange). Which brings us to the ghost stories. Ghosts, it seems, are especially attracted to theaters, and Gavin's tour includes mentions of apparitions both at the Beacham and in several other theatrical venues}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hauntedplaces.org/item/tabu-nightclub-the-beacham/ |title=Tabu Nightclub - The Beacham |author= |date= |website=hauntedplaces.org |publisher=Haunted Places (blog) |access-date=August 14, 2016 |quote=}}{{cite web|url=http://pegasus.cc.ucf.edu/~joupage/evan/morgenstern.html|title=Orlando: the City Haunted|last=Anderson|first=Vanessa|date=2001|website=Orlando: the City Haunted|publisher=Knightwire|access-date=August 14, 2016|quote=|last1=|first1=}} The Beacham's [[auditorium]] features "square [[columns]] adorned with feathered [[Capital (architecture)|capitals]] that climb gracefully to a high ceiling decorated with rectangles of intricate [[plasterwork]]." When constructed, the theater was outfitted with [[Curtain|draperies]] that covered the plaster walls. The draperies had "mild tan figures delicately woven into the broad white field with an occasional soft blue figure" that were selected by Mrs. Roberta Holland Beacham, wife of Braxton Beacham Sr. [[File:Beacham Theater in 1921.jpg|thumb|230px|left|The Beacham Theatre shortly after construction in 1921]] Beacham outfitted his theater with innovative state-of-the art equipment from the Southern Theater Equipment Company of Atlanta.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-12-04/news/0090000006_1_bookhardt-beacham-sidewalks|title=1907: Beacham Elected Mayor|last1=Glover|first1=C.A.|date=December 4, 1988|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 16, 2016 |quote=}} The Beacham's box office in the lobby featured both an automatic [[admission ticket]] [[vending machine]] dispenser and ticket [[cutting|chopping]] machine. A decorative [[Marquee (sign)|marquee]] that was unique in Florida extended toward the street and featured an electric changeable sign that flashed the daily program. Two Powers 6B type "E" projectors were supplied by the N Power company of New York. The Midas Gold [[Projection screen|film screen]] was made especially for the Beacham. A medium-sized [[pipe organ]] from the [[Austin Organ Company]] of [[Hartford, Connecticut]], was purchased and installed at a cost of $15,000. The organ, [[List of pipe organs|Opus 1034]] with 3 [[Manual (music)|manual]]s in a center [[Organ console|console]], 24 ranks of [[Organ pipes|pipes]] and 24 [[Organ stop|stops]][http://www.austinorgans.com/aoisearchableopus.html Austin Organs Database], retrieved October 14, 2016. was played by both Mr. Herman Stuart and Mrs. Roberta Branch Beacham, wife of Braxton Beacham Jr. to accompany [[silent film]]s and [[vaudeville]] acts. Typhoon cooling and ventilating equipment was installed in the theater. The Beacham Building's construction featured numerous [[fireproofing]] and [[fire safety]] measures. When the theater opened, the auditorium had an operating capacity of 1400.{{cite news |author= |title=New Beacham is one of Refinement and Elegance: Equipment of New Beacham Theater is the Finest that is Obtainable. |url= |newspaper= The Evening Reporter-Star.|location=Orlando. |date=December 8, 1921 |access-date= }} [[Tunnels]] from the theater stage trap ran into the basements of two nearby hotels. The tunnels had low ceilings and were sealed during new construction in the early 1980s. The tunnels extended south into the [[San Juan Hotel]], where Mr. Beacham happened to have had an office, and then east under Orange Avenue into the [[Angebilt Hotel]]. Historians reason that the purpose of the tunnels may have been either for vaudeville performers to enter the theater from their hotels without being mobbed by crowds, or the tunnels could have been used for the storage and transportation of alcoholic beverages during prohibition as has been discovered at some of the other theaters in the Central Florida area.{{cite book|author=Steve Rajtar|title=A Guide to Historic Orlando|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3cZfqYU1B4cC&pg=PA58|year=2006|publisher=The History Press|isbn=978-1-59629-198-0|pages=58–}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-02-10/news/HISTORYTRAILS_1_historic-trails-boy-scout-florida|title=Take a walk into Florida's past |last1=Shrieves |first1=Linda |date=February 10, 2007|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= ''The Orlando Sentinel''|access-date= August 5, 2016|quote=Behind the theater's backstage is a trap door to a tunnel that runs underneath Orange Avenue to the 11-story brick building that was once the grand Angebilt Hotel. The tunnel was built, he says, so that vaudeville stars appearing at the Beacham in the 1920s, '30s and '40s could slip back to the hotel after the show without being mobbed by fans.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.orlandomagazine.com/Orlando-Magazine/July-2012/Answer-Man/ |title= Digging into Orlando's Past: Is there a secret tunnel connecting the Beacham Theater and the old Angebilt Hotel? |author= |date=July 12, 2012 |website=orlandomagazine.com |publisher= Orlando Magazine|access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=Another Orlando historian, Joy Wallace Dickinson, raises an intriguing possibility about the Beacham. Recently she toured some historic buildings in Tampa and learned that during renovation, crews came across subterranean spaces about 3 feet high that were used to hide booze during Prohibition.}} ===Vaudeville and Silent film era=== On December 9, 1921, Orlando's premier vaudeville and movie house opened by showing [[Norma Talmadge filmography|''The Wonderful Thing'']], starring [[Norma Talmadge]], a [[Pathé News]] [[newsreel]], and [[Buster Keaton]]'s ''[[The Boat (film)|The Boat]]''.Act Two: A Beacham History. 1985. Celebrity Dinner Theater.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-12-31/news/0012300184_1_magruder-carter-third-millennium |title=Hoofbeats Were Background To New Year's 1901 |author= |date=December 31, 2000 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 4, 2016 |quote=}} The Beacham Theatre was originally the only [[sole proprietorship|independent]] theater in Orlando. However, the next year, in 1922, Beacham leased his theater to Mack Sparks of the Sparks Theater Company chain. [[File:San Juan Hotel and Beacham Theater - Orlando, Florida.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Beacham Theatre and San Juan Hotel circa 1923. Marquee: The Second Orlando Picture The Burned Crucifix]] The senior Braxton Beacham died in 1924 after a long illness, and Roberta Holland Beacham died soon after in 1926. Their [[Estate (law)|estate]] and [[real property]] were left to their [[child]]ren, Norma K. Hughes, Roberta Augusta Rogers, Braxton Beacham Jr., and his wife Roberta Branch Beacham. [[Florida]] and [[Orlando]] were on what was referred to by [[List of vaudeville performers: A–K|vaudeville performers]] as "[[Straw hat|The Straw Hat]] [[Atlantic Coast Line Railroad|Circuit]]." The Beacham Theatre was included on the [[Alexander Pantages]], [[Orpheum Circuit#Late circuit (1919–1928)|Orpheum]], and [[Keith-Albee Theatre|Keith-Albee]] vaudeville performance circuits (later combined as the [[Keith-Albee-Orpheum]] circuit). Manager Harry Vincent started several promotions at the Beacham Theatre in the summer months of the mid-1920s that included [[Raffle|Bank Night]], [[Talent show|Amateur Night]], and [[General store|Country Store Night]], which was supported by dozens of local [[merchant]]s. An [[magazine|advertisement]] for the Beacham in 1925 says, "Don't talk about the hot weather. Beat the heat in a Beacham seat. 'Kum Keep Kumfy Kool at the Beacham' is known to many and you won't enjoy yourself until you too get into the line that leads to comfort."What's What, Here and There as Recorded by "Bobby" (1925) magazine. Theatrical section via LMS, Orange County Public Library. Orlando. Frank Bell served as manager of the theater with [[organist]] Herman Siewart and Ken Guernsey leading the community [[sing-along]] at [[Forum (legal)|open forum]] meetings that were held for several months during the winter on Sunday afternoons. The Beacham's "[[Film promotion|exploitation]] director" Frank H. Burns often designed and created large elaborate [[standee|standing displays]] that decorated the facade and lobby of the theater in order to [[Out-of-home advertising|advertise]] new film features.{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/motionpicturenew00moti_7/motionpicturenew00moti_7_djvu.txt|title=Motion Picture News (May-Jun 1925)"|last=|first=|date=May 2, 1925|website=mediahistoryproject.org|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art Library coordinated by the Media History Digital Library|archive-url=https://archive.org/details/motionpicturenew00moti_7|archive-date=July 3, 2015|access-date=August 24, 2016}} The iconic displays that Burns created for the Beacham Theatre were sometimes complete with [[Costume coordination|coordinated costumes]] for the employees. In 1928 [[Vitaphone]] and [[Movietone sound system|Movietone]] [[Sound film|"talkie"]] equipment debuted during the city's first "Progress Week" during the last week of August. "The queen of the [[Femme fatale|vamps]]," [[actress]] [[Theda Bara]], was in appearance at the Beacham as [[secondary education in the United States|students]] from [[Orange County Public Schools#High schools|Orlando High School]] sneaked into the balcony via the [[fire escape]]. Sound was provided by two [[gramophone records|gramophone discs]] that accompanied each film. Both [[phonograph]]s were played simultaneously in case the needle skipped during a film. Output could be easily switched so that the film's sound could remain in [[synchronicity]] with the picture. William Booth succeeded Frank Bell as manager of the Beacham after Bell was transferred in 1928. The city's "[[Blue law|Sunday closing law]]" was repealed by [[Voting|voters]] in 1929 by a majority of only 59 votes. Movie theaters and other businesses in Orlando were then permitted to operate seven days a week. All of Orlando's theaters, including the Beacham, celebrated by showing free films until late into the night.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 1996|title=Retroactively Speaking|url=|journal=Downtown Orlando Monthly|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|via=Theatre Historical Society of America}} ==== End of the vaudeville and silent film era ==== Interest in silent films began to diminish in 1929 and they were gradually phased out and moved into [[obsolescence]]. On Thursday evenings at the Beacham for the Bank Night promotion, $200 was [[raffle]]d with prizes of $50. On Saturday, December 24, 1931, and on Wednesday, September 28, 1932, a brand new $325 [[Austin 7#Austin Seven Swallow|Austin 7 Sport Roadster]] was given away. Vaudeville acts continued touring at the Beacham for several more years until approximately 1933. Homer Fuller served as manager of the Beacham during the end of the eras of silent films and vaudeville. In 1933 following a bitter [[lawsuit]] against Orlando Enterprises over nonpayment of the lease for the building that had been originally negotiated with the senior Braxton Beacham in 1924, the theater was closed for almost three weeks. $8000 in back taxes on Beacham's building was due. Beacham Jr. claimed the closure was deliberate and malicious and sued for $100,000. Two separate judgments were entered against Orlando Enterprises Inc. for $2291.67 each and a payment agreement was reached. Litigation was then withdrawn. As a result of the suit the lease was not renewed and Beacham's theater again became Orlando's only independent cinema.[https://orlandoretro.com/2013/04/18/beacham-movie-line-up-in-september-1933/ Beacham Movie Line Up in September 1933] (April 18, 2013), retrieved February 9, 2017 In the same year, the theater was soon leased Florida State Theaters. Harry Vincent was named manager of the reopened theater in 1933; however, soon after, Vernon D. Hunter became the theater's manager and remained in that role for the next two decades. ===First-Run Movie era=== In August 1937 the [[Orlando Police Department]] raided the Beacham Theatre. All of the equipment for the Bank Night [[Promotion (marketing)|marketing promotion]] was [[Search and seizure|seized]] after authorities declared it to be a [[lottery]].{{cite book|author=Eve Bacon|title=Orlando: A Centennial History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4svzPQAACAAJ|year=1977|publisher=Mickler House}} ''[[The Yearling (film)|The Yearling]]'' was filmed locally in 1946 and the Beacham's [[projectionist]] Byram McGee served as an [[Electrician (theatre)|electrician]] and steward on the [[Production (film)|film production]]. Mcgee's wife Lois [[Actor|acted]] in the role of Ma Forrester and was also the production's [[wardrobe supervisor]]. Numerous other local [[technician]]s were involved with making the film. ''[[The Orlando Story]]'', filmed by Don Parrisher Motion Picture Productions of New York, contained images of daily life in Orlando. The movie was heavily promoted locally and was shown at the Beacham over three days in August 1949.{{cite web |url=http://dc.ocls.info/memory/document/orlando-story |title=The Orlando Story |author= |date=July 7, 2012 |website=Orlando Memory |publisher=Orange County Library System|access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=...promoting a movie created about daily life in Orlando called ''The Orlando Story''. ... The film was shown for three days - August 11, 12, and 13 at ... the Beacham...These scenes were shot by Don Parrisher Motion Picture Productions, of New York, some months ago; now you can see them on the Beacham and Roxy screens.}} [[File:The Robe Beacham Theatre student ticket.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Student ticket for ''The Robe'' and the debut of CinemaScope at the Beacham Theatre]] In December 1949 ''The [[Tom Thumb]] [[Follies]]'' staged [[Radio in the United States#Local radio in the Golden Age|radio broadcast]] performances at the Beacham. When a [[Santa Claus]] from the [[Elks Lodge]] lifted one young elf into the audience for the last verse, the smell of [[bourbon whiskey]] caused her to ponder, "I wasn't just sure where the night's polka would land us. Maybe [[Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|Oz]]?"{{cite magazine |last=Weber III |first=Theodore H. |date=December 25, 1994 |title=Oh Little Town... |url= |magazine=Florida Magazine |location=Orlando |publisher=Florida magazine via Rollins College, Olin Library |access-date=}} After an extensive remodel, [[CinemaScope]] equipment was introduced at the "New" Beacham Theatre in 1954 with the addition of [[stereophonic sound]], new projection [[Lens (optics)|lens]]es, and a wider screen.{{cite web |url=http://www2.boxoffice.com/the_vault/issue_page?issue_id=1954-1-9&page_no=118#page_start|title=Impressive new Facade for Florida Theatre |author= |date=January 9, 1954|website=boxoffice.com |publisher=[[Boxoffice Magazine]] |access-date=August 11, 2016 |quote=}} CinemaScope had its debut at the Beacham on January 7, 1954, for a two-week showing of the film ''[[The Robe (film)|The Robe]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.film-tech.com/ubb/f1/t011551.html|title=Looking back at CinemaScope: The Original Engagements of ''The Robe'' |last1= Coate |first1=Michael|date=September 16, 2013 |website=film-tech.com |publisher= |access-date=August 28, 2016 |quote=}} Vernon D. Hunter retired after 20 years as manager of the Beacham Theater. Walther Colby became the executive director of several Orlando theaters including the Beacham. Braxton Beacham Jr., died in 1961. [[File:Beacham Theatre Box Office.jpg|thumb|left|210px|The box office of the Beacham Theatre in March 1991. The 1954 box office was removed in 2000.]] During the [[Civil Rights Movement]], the Beacham Theatre had frequent [[Sit-in|stand-in protest]]s by [[African Americans|African American]] [[Citizenship|citizens]] of relegation to lesser "[[African-American|colored]] theaters" mandated by [[Jim Crow laws]] such as the [[Florida Constitution of 1885]]. [[Reverend]] [[Nelson Pinder]], of [[Parramore]]'s Episcopal Church of St. John the Baptist, along with other community leaders such as NAACP Youth Council advisor, Rev. Curtis Jackson, worked with white officials for peaceful integration in Orlando in order to avoid incidents of [[racial violence]] that were occurring in other Florida cities.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2010-01-08/news/os-father-pinder-recognitiion-20100108_1_episcopal-diocese-bishop-john-w-howe-episcopal-church-official |title=Episcopal diocese honors Nelson Pinder for 50 years in ministry|last1= Kunerth |first1=Jeff |date= January 8, 2010|website= |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 30, 2016 |quote=}} Rev. Pinder organized the church's Liberal Religious Youth group.{{Cite web|url=https://ucf.digital.flvc.org/islandora/object/ucf%3A25551/datastream/OBJ/view/The_Florida_historical_quarterly.pdf |title=Segregation and Desegregation in Parramore: Orlando's African American Community|last=Mosier Porter|first=Tana|date=Winter 2004|website=The Florida Historical Quarterly. Volume 82, Number 3|publisher=The Florida Historical Society|access-date=August 23, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/features/os-black-teens-civil-rights-story.html |title=Teens spark Orlando's civil-rights era |last= Kunerth |first= Jeff|date=February 22, 2009 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=November 21, 2016 |quote=Some of the youths worked with the Rev. Nelson Pinder, a young Episcopalian minister of the streets. Others, such as those arrested in March 1962, were members of the NAACP Youth Council, a local chapter started in 1959...Two months after being released from jail, Poston was arrested again for trying to integrate the Beacham Theater in downtown Orlando. Joining a group of black kids, Poston stood in line for tickets, was refused, got back in line and continued the routine until the last ticket was sold. Their courteous protest drew the attention of young white segregationists who threatened the black teens. Orlando police arrived and arrested the eight black students for "disturbing the peace." Police later said the blacks were taken into protective custody to prevent violence against them. All were released because they were underage -- except 18-year-old Sandra Poston, who called her mother from jail. "I thought, 'Here it goes again,' " her mother said. That charge and all the charges against the kids arrested at Stroud's were eventually dismissed...1963: Beacham Theater agrees to allow limited numbers of blacks at designated showings.}} Rev. Pinder's youth group protests were often joined by local members of the Youth Council of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]]. Each night, activist members of the youth groups quietly stood-in near the Beacham's ticket booth until the theater stopped selling tickets. On May 24, 1962, [[white supremacists]] were also [[picketing]] the Beacham at the same time as the Liberal Religious Youth group. Orlando police [[arrest]]ed eight teen protestors. The teens were kept in so-called [[Protective custody#Other usages|protective custody]] and were later released to their parents. Following agreements with a [[biracial]] [[committee]] from [[List of mayors of Orlando, Florida|Orlando Mayor]] [[Bob Carr (Florida politician)|Bob Carr]]'s office, of which Rev. Pinder was a member, the Beacham Theatre quietly began allowing a limited number of African-American patrons into the balcony for designated showings in 1963. The theater remained [[Racial segregation in the United States|racially segregated]] for African-American patrons until 1965.{{cite web |url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/10862 |title=Beacham Theater|last1=Jennings|first1=Samuel|date=June 18, 2011 |website= cinematreasures.org|publisher= Cinema Treasures|access-date=August 5, 2016|quote=}} In 1964 the theater was temporarily closed down while [[Cinerama]] equipment was installed. A super-wide [[Anamorphic widescreen|anamorphic movie screen]] was added to the auditorium and the stereophonic sound system was upgraded. Two [[Philips DP70|Norelco Universal 70/35mm Motion Picture Projector]]s and a small restroom for the projectionist were installed in a newly built downstairs projection booth under the balcony that required the removal of two aisles and several seats. Following the Beacham's upgrade to [[70 mm film]] technology, ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'' had a continuous 14-month run between 1965 and 1966. Orlando's [[Chamber of Commerce]] held open forum meetings at the Beacham Theatre on Sundays during the winter months of 1971-1973 under the direction of W. F. Blackman. ====End of the first-run movie era==== [[File:Old Beacham Theatre logo sticker.jpg|thumb|200px|left|1990's logo depicting the Beacham Theatre's mid-century marquee.]] During the 1970s Orlando, like many U.S. cites, was experiencing symptoms of [[urban decay]]. The rush from the city to the suburbs affected nearly all of the city's businesses. As an effect of the exodus, each of Downtown Orlando's movie theaters closed. Dick Gabel and John Prine were serving as projectionists at several of the theaters. Following a decline in attendance, by 1974 the Beacham Theatre and Florida State Theaters in general were primarily showing [[exploitation films]] and [[B movie#1970s|B-movie]] [[action films]]. The next year, H. A. Tedder, who was the Orlando executive manager at long-time [[lessee]] Florida State Theaters, made the decision that The Beacham Theatre would cease operating as a first-run movie cinema. After showing a Sunday double-feature of ''[[Return of the Street Fighter]]'', and [[The Scavengers (1969 film)|''The Scavengers'']], the Beacham Theatre's manager, McKinley Howard, closed the theater's doors as a first-run film cinema for the last time on September 28, 1975.Last picture Show: Beacham. September 28, 1975. Florida State Theaters remained responsible for paying the monthly lease of $2700 until the theater was sold. ===Live Entertainment era=== In 1975 Larry and Sherry Carpenter purchased the Beacham Building from then-owners, Betty Rubles Bray, and Burkett H. Bray Jr. A [[great-granddaughter]] of Braxton Beacham, Mrs. Bray, refused to sell the theater by itself without also selling the rest of the building as a package. An extensive $250,000 remodeling and restoration followed that included stunning multi-colored Art Deco revival style graphics painted over the facade and a large multi-story [[mural]] of a saxophone and its open case painted on the rear of the theater that faced west and was clearly visible from nearby [[Interstate 4]]. Following the restoration the Carpenters opened Orlando's [[Franchising|franchise]] location of '''The Great Southern Music Hall''' at the Beacham in 1976. The 700-seat Great Southern Music Hall was a [[concert venue]] that hosted approximately 180 prominent national and regional acts at the Beacham. The Great Southern Music Hall was occasionally still used as a movie theater that presented [[world cinema]] and [[Classical Hollywood cinema|classic Hollywood]] films by [[film director]]s such as [[John Carpenter]], [[Federico Fellini]], and [[Mel Brooks]] during the week. John Lawson was the acting projectionist and served as stage director for concerts. As The Great Southern Music Hall, only about seven music shows were unprofitable. Nevertheless, Orlando's Great Southern Music Hall closed in 1981 due to the rising costs of hosting concerts for [[Notability|notable]] musical acts and competition from larger venues. Roberta Branch Beacham died in 1980. [[File:Beacham Theatre mural 1.jpg|thumb|220px|Mural on Beacham Theater in 1983]] In 1981 Sherry Carpenter, then sole owner, leased the theater to Jeff Roberts. Roberts opened '''Laser World''', a [[futuristic]] one- and one-half hour [[laser light show]] that featured [[lasers]], [[sound]], [[ballet]], costumed [[modern dance]] routines and [[Magic (illusion)|magic]] [[illusion]], as well as [[outer space]] [[photographs]] that were projected onto a large viewing screen from behind. Laser World closed in 1982. Other short-lasting entities followed such as a [[Tourism|tourist-oriented]] [[laser tag]] business.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ''[[Orlando Sentinel|The Orlando Sentinel]]'' critic Howard Means, reminded readers, that the 1965 installation of "then-new [[Cinerama]] equipment at the Beacham was the latest testimony to the faith in the future of Downtown Orlando" and that, "The Beacham had long been seen as a bellwether of the health of the center city." Upon further reflection, he lamented, "that the Beacham is simply a microcosm of modern downtown realities." Means editorialized, by 1982 "The present state of the Beacham was the latest testament to decay," and, "In the way of dying enterprises, the Beacham's reincarnations became increasingly more short-lived." In February 1983 Oscar F. Juarez, an Orlando [[Real estate development|property developer]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] [[strategist]], purchased the building for $1.5 million.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-04-07/news/0030160194_1_beacham-juarez-board-members |title=Goodbye Voted For Beacham Board Says Owner May Tear Old Theater Down|last1=Benedick |first1=Robin |date=April 7, 1988 |website= |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 24, 2016 |quote=}} Soon after the purchase, a plan was announced to lease it in order to open a [[bar]] and French restaurant "with a [[Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)|Georgetown]] flair" that later became Valentyne's Restaurant as well as a new nightclub inside the theater. A vision for the theater announced in 1983 was for a New York-style nightclub dubbed '''Studio 46''' that emulated the spirit of the legendary "[[Studio 54]]." Studio 46 did not come to fruition but the primordial description of Orlando's very own "Studio 54" at the Beacham Theater was soon realized just a few years later.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2013-06-27/entertainment/os-jim-abbott-aahz-reunion-orlando-20130627_1_legacy-third-wave-dj-kimball-collins |title= Make a return to AAHZ once more|last1=Abbott |first1= Jim |date=June 27, 2013|website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote= Gazing upward at the high ceiling inside The Beacham, DJ Kimball Collins reflects on the role that the building itself had on the mystique of AAHZ, the progressive house-music parties that put Orlando on the international map as a hotbed of electronic music in the early 1990s..."We always wanted people to come experience it here," Collins says of the Beacham. "This is like our Studio 54; there's just something about this room." Between roughly 1989 and 1992, AAHZ blossomed into a weekly all-night Saturday dance party that attracted devoted fans who would travel from across the state to dance until daylight. "There's a scene in the movie '54,' when one of the characters walks into the club for the first time and everything just slows down and it's sensory overload,"... That philosophy yielded AAHZ, a concept eternally beloved by its fans and those who created it..."It still has some sort of energy in here for them," Collins says, looking around the room. "We feel it." }} The theater was next leased by Ellen Hunt, of Orlando, and Roger Lopez, of [[France]] in August 1983. Hunt and Lopez opened a [[cabaret]] club in the theater named '''[[Moulin Rouge|Moulin Orange]]''' that featured [[Las Vegas]]-style [[showgirl]]s.{{Cite news|title=Curtain Call for Old Beacham Theater|last=Hagstrom|first=Suzy|date=November 5, 1984|work=The Orlando Sentinel|via=}} Moulin Orange was only open for several months during 1983 and 1984. In December 1984 with the hope of operating an expansion to his [[dinner theater]] franchise, a five-year lease of the theater was granted to Theatre Management Corporation of Orlando consisting of [[actor]] Tom McKinney and Rick Allen, a producer of the [[Burt Reynolds#Other roles|Reynolds]] Theater. The Beacham served as a '''Celebrity Dinner Theater''' franchise location in conjunction with Valentyne's [[restaurant]] that was next door from 1985 until 1986.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-11-03/lifestyle/0080110137_1_beacham-liberace-belletto |title=Theater Revival At The Beacham Won't Last Long |last1= Maupin|first1=Elizabeth |date=November 3, 1988 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 10, 2016|quote=The Beacham -- which closed as a movie house in 1975 -- has stood empty off and on for years, between incarnations as the Great Southern Music Hall, Celebrity Dinner Theater and a number of shorter-lived enterprises. As Celebrity Dinner Theater, the building was used from February 1985 to January 1986 and, under other management, again for the first several months of 1987. Since then it has been used occasionally for concerts but has fallen into disrepair.}} Under new management, '''Valentyne's Celebrity Dinner Theater''' briefly reopened in 1986 before the dinner theater venture at the Beacham finally ended entirely early in 1987. The Beacham Theatre was granted local historic landmark status on September 21, 1987, for its historical significance to the community. Between each new identity for the theater and the occasional concert, the Beacham Theatre sat [[Occupancy#Building utilization|unoccupied]] and empty. [[File:Beacham Theatre ceiling and columns in March 1991.jpg|thumb|200px|"Square columns and feathered capitals climb gracefully to intricate plasterwork" in 1991.]] Despite the new recognition for the theater by the City of Orlando, Mr. Juarez saw the building as a liability with many pleasant memories surrounding it, but with little economic potential. Citing maintaining the building and rehabilitation of the area, he first announced plans to raze the building for an unspecified mix-use purpose and later to redevelop the former Beacham Block with a new [[skyscraper]] that would be used as a combination office building and hotel.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1987-07-13/business/0180230093_1_juarez-magnolia-avenue-orange-avenue |title=Juarez Building Finally Fills Up Developer Considers Building Second Office Project|last1=Snyder |first1= Jack|date=July 13, 1987 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=September 4, 2016 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1987-08-23/news/0140190075_1_historic-preservation-landmark-beacham |title=Historic Label No Guarantee Beacham Theater's Owner May Raze Old Downtown Building For New One |last1=Patrizio |first1= Ron |date=August 23, 1987 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 10, 2016|quote=The Beacham Theater has served as a city hall, vaudeville playhouse and movie theater. In 1975, it closed as a movie theater and reopened a year later as the Great Southern Music Hall. It finally closed as the Celebrity Dinner Theater in January.}} In 1988 Juarez received two successive approval [[Construction permit|Certificate of Appropriateness permits]] from the City of Orlando Board of Historic Preservation to [[demolish]] the Beacham Theatre within 180 days. The "Bye-bye Beacham [[Party|Bash]]" was promptly organized by Orlando Remembered and attended by former theater [[doorman (profession)|doormen]], [[usher (occupation)|usher]]s, [[Cigarette girl (person)|candy girl]]s, and [[cashier]]s on December 9, 1988.{{Cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1988-12-06/lifestyle/0090020027_1_beacham-bye-historical-displays|title=Beacham Does Its Bit For History 'Bye-bye Bash' A Benefit For Downtown Displays|last=Hodges|first=Sam|date=December 6, 1988|website=The Orlando Sentinel|publisher=The Orlando Sentinel|access-date=August 23, 2016}} However, Mr. Juarez's redevelopment plan and the new construction of a 20-story [[office building]] and [[parking garage]] fell through at the last moment due to poor timing. Additional parking could have contributed to a revitalized downtown area, but the market for office space in Downtown Orlando was nearly saturated in the late 1980s and there was a general lack of interest from prospective future [[tenants]]. Had the project materialized, Mr. Juaraz would have been required to reconstruct a [[replica]] of the original Beacham Theatre [[facade]] using original [[building materials]] of brick, stucco, decorative tile, and pastel colors. [[File:Beacham Theatre facade in 1991.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Beacham Theatre facade in March 1991]] In 1987 Brad Belletto and then-wife Lisa moved to Orlando from [[Louisiana]]. Brad Belletto, then owned a theatrical equipment manufacturing company and had formerly owned Moon Sound, a [[New Orleans]] sound and lighting company. The Bellettos, intent on overhauling the music scene in Orlando, were looking for a new venue following operation of a successful club in [[Baton Rouge]]. They found the Beacham Theatre and immediately fell in love with it. At that time, the Beacham was being subleased to Clark J, a local record producer, and a brief partnership was formed. Late in 1988 the lease for the Beacham's theater was secured by the Bellettos under Entertainment Investments International.{{cite news |last=Mathers |first=Sandra |date=December 22, 1991 |title=Theater Plans Holiday Treat For Homeless|url= http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-12-22/news/9112200744_1_dinner-hammersmith-belletto|newspaper=''the Orlando Sentinel'' |location=Orlando |access-date= October 13, 2016|quote=The sit-down dinner is the brainchild of Brad and Lisa Belletto, whose Entertainment Investments company operates the theater and jazz club...Belletto said he patterned the dinner after a similar theater event he was involved with in New Orleans.}} Several of Lisa's cousins relocated to Orlando to help out with the task of preparing the Beacham for its opening and Brad's mother Bev tended the bar through the entire duration of the lease. The Bellettos also hosted an annual full-service Christmas dinner for hundreds of the city's homeless population at the Beacham Theatre with food donated by Orlando's high-end restaurants and businesses. The Bellettos planned to use the Beacham Theatre for [[Theatre|theatrical]] performances and concerts during the week and as a [[nightclub]] on the weekends. Frank Carroll, served as the managing artistic director for theatre productions and starred in a [[Las Vegas]]-style musical [[revue]] tribute to [[Liberace]], ''Viva Liberace, Viva''. A "[[Leonard Bernstein]] opera" and "an [[Edward Albee]] drama" were additional [[Theatrical production|production]] features before theatrical productions ceased. Concerts were coordinated by Mary Ann D'Arpino of Mary Ann Productions, who had an office at the Beacham; Island Productions; Harry Tiyler of Fat Harry Productions, and Cellar Door Productions. Several prominent musical act [[concert]]s of nearly every genre were staged during this time. === Night Club era === Since 1988 the theater has been used as a series of combination [[nightclub]] and [[concert venue]] [[Business|enterprises]]. In May 1989 the Beacham Theatre was sold by Oscar Juarez for $1.8 million to a [[property management]] firm owned by [[Longwood, Florida|Longwood]] businesswoman Missy Casscells and her husband Frank Hamby.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-10-31/business/9210310587_1_blues-club-beacham-alcoholic-beverage |title=State Files To Revoke Club's Liquor License|last1= Jackson|first1=Jerry |date=October 31, 1992 |website= orlandosentinel.com|publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 20, 2016 |quote=A Longwood businesswoman who owns the historic Beacham Theatre building in which the nightclub was located said she hopes to see some kind of similar club operation continue. "We want something in there that Orlando can be proud of," said Missy Casscells, a property manager who owns the Beacham building on Orange Avenue. Casscells, 32, said she has owned the Beacham building since May 1989. She said it was acquired from Oscar Juarez, a well-known Orlando businessman and Republican party activist, for about $1.8 million. Casscells said she and her husband, Frank Hamby, manage their family-owned property}} ==== Late Night era: (1988–1994) Aahz ==== Brad and Lisa Belletto scoured sources across the U.S. and Europe and traveled frequently for new and rare records. During the [[Second Summer of Love]] in the [[United Kingdom]] that began in 1988, on Friday and Saturday nights the Beacham Theater housed a [[discothèque|discotheque]] that had a progressive dance music format with Lisa Belletto as resident DJ and lighting control operator and Brad Belletto as operating director. Initially the club was to be called "[[Special effect|'''F/X''' (or '''Effects''')]]"Beacham Theatre Returns! 1988. Brad Belletto. but it opened as [[Hi-NRG|'''Pure Energy''']]. The late nights at the Beacham featured [[disc jockeys|DJs]], [[Beatmatching|beat matching]], [[Rare groove|rare and obscure]] [[dance music]] on [[Gramophone record|vinyl records]], [[intelligent lighting]], and themed decor that at times included original [[painting]]s by local artist Rollo. The popularity of dancing throughout the night at the Beacham Theatre initially caught on slowly and many free passes were given out. Soon, the entry queue for "Late Night" snaked around the block. The conceptual themes for "Late Night" were frequently alternated (sometimes weekly) and occasionally repeated. The various themes subsequently included '''[[World War III]]''', [[Land of Oz|'''Aahz''']], [[Last Train to Trancentral#Trancentral|'''Trancentral''']], '''[[Haunted house|The Haunted Theatre]]''', [[Egypt#Prehistory and Ancient Egypt|'''Egypt''']], '''[[Alphabet City]]''', '''Psychedelic Babylon''', '''[[Unity (mathematics)|Unity]]''', and '''[[family reunion|Reunion]]'''. The all-night [[Dance party|dance parties]] were eventually referred to using the [[umbrella term]] "'Late Night' at the Classic Beacham Theatre." The Aahz nightclub concept was born after Lisa saw the name at a shop in [[Los Angeles]]. The Bellettos and Shayni Howen then created and developed the Aahz concept for the Beacham. Shayni and her team created Aahz's iconic décor which included a painted yellow brick road and a giant [[paper mache]] [[Wizard of Oz (character)|Wizard of Oz]] head behind the stage. At midnight each night, the stage's curtain was raised and the glowing eyes and smoking mouth of the Wizard were revealed, at which point DJ Lisa always played Rhythm Device's ''Acid Rock''. Eventually the combined tasks of simultaneously playing all of the music and operating the lights became overwhelming for Lisa and as a result Shayni's sister, "Late night" veteran Stacey "StaceBass" Howen, was brought in to operate the computerized [[lighting control console]] and [[Promoter (entertainment)|promote]] the nightclub. By the Summer of 1989, Lisa was expecting her first child and still resident DJ. Only two months before the birth of her son she invited Kimball Collins, who was the DJ in the Beacham Buildings northern unit, to replace her and hired him as Aahz's resident Late Night DJ. Joseph Jilbert (DJ Jo-Edd), Steve McClure (DJ Monk) and Paul Campbell (DJ Stylus) had brief stints as DJ at "Late Night" when they were hired to fill in for Lisa or Kimball Collins. Dave Cannalte was quickly brought in as "Late Night's" co-resident DJ. At this point, [[Underground music]] such as [[Industrial dance music]] and [[Gothic rock]] was played during Orlando's normal [[bar]] operating hours from 10 p.m. until just after 2 a.m. Upon an announcement at around 2:30 a.m. (or an opening at 3 a.m.) that said simply, "Welcome to Late Night," mixed [[New Beat]], [[Progressive house|Progressive dance]], [[Balearic beat]], and [[Acid house]] electronic dance music began that frequently lasted until 8 a.m. and occasionally lasted until as late as 11 a.m. Local DJ's Jerry Johnson (''the Reverend''), Andy Hughes, Jay Skinner, Robby Clark, Troy Davis, Eddie Pappa ([[DJ Icey]]) and DJ Lisa Belletto were occasional guests for special events such as the "DJ Unity for the World" dance party in December 1991.{{cite news |last=Abbott |first= Jim|date=December 6, 1991 |title=Public Enemy To Play Orlando |url= http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-12-06/entertainment/9112050582_1_ron-brooks-downtown-orlando-concert|newspaper=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |location= Orlando|access-date=October 12, 2016|quote=Saturday, the Beacham Theatre will host DJ Unity for the World, a dance party featuring the talents of Central Florida club deejays Jerry ''the Reverend'' Johnson, Lisa Belletto, Andy Hughes, Jay Skinner, Robby Clark, Troy Davis, DJ Ice, the Dave Cannalte and Kimball Collins. }} [[File:The Return of Aahz on Saturday, September 7, 1991.jpg|thumb|180px|left|1991 Return of AAHZ flyer]] Dave Cannalte and Kimball Collins, and Stace presided over and further developed an ever-growing local scene. [[Chris Fortier]] later joined the duo of Kimball and Dave Cannalte as an Aahz resident DJ. As it evolved, "Late Night" boosted the careers of numerous DJs and producers such as Andy Hughes, [[Jimmy Van M]], [[AK1200]], [[DJ Icey]], [[DJ Baby Anne]], Sean Cusick, and [[Cosmic Baby]], as well as [[Dave Seaman]], [[Sasha (Welsh DJ)|Sasha]] and [[John Digweed]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pandora.com/station/329fee63a4f3e82d33c4865fe69c7bea68f6545495cedc47 |title=John Digweed Radio |last1= Montes De Oca|first1=Mark |date= May 5, 2008|website=pandora.com |publisher=Pandora |access-date=September 2, 2016 |quote=Digweed came to the United States through Orlando, FL and had this to say about that night, "It wasn't until 1993, when I did a big party in Orlando, that it kicked things off for Sasha and I. [[File:Death of Aahz.jpg|thumb|180px|1992 Death of AAHZ flyer]] ====Cultural impact==== The early mornings at the Beacham Theatre kick started Orlando's own [[Summer of Love]] between 1991 and 1992 that helped usher in the increased popularity of the [[Clubbing (subculture)|subculture]] surrounding [[electronic dance music]] in Florida and subsequently in the United States. "Late Night" organized several [[music festival]]s that were held at the [[Orange County Convention Center]] such as the "[[Infinity (philosophy)|Infonet]]" DJ spinoff on October 24, 1992, the "Infonet 2" dance party on December 31, 1992, and "Infonet 3," "The Underground Explosion," on July 3, 1993. Subsequent large-event promoters failed to emulate the spirit of those events. Although, "[[rave]]s" per se were not held in the Theater, the Beacham served as the prototype for nearly all of the larger so-called [[Electronic dance music#Popularization in the United States|rave-oriented]] nightclubs that followed it.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1993-08-01/news/9308010603_1_rave-downtown-orlando-spinoffs |title= All The Rave|last1=Guinto |first1= Liesl |date=August 1, 1993 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 16, 2016 |quote=The Orlando rave scene can trace its roots back almost five years to the old Beacham Theatre in downtown Orlando, also known as Aahz. Other clubs followed in the footsteps of Aahz, including The Edge in downtown Orlando, The Coliseum in Daytona Beach and Marz in Cocoa Beach.}}{{cite web |url=https://www.insomniac.com/media/candy-ravers-and-psychonauts-florida-rave-scene |title=Candy Ravers and Psychonauts: The Florida Rave Scene |last1=Guida |first1=Humberto |date=November 21, 2014 |website=insomniac.com |publisher=Insomniac |access-date=August 17, 2016 |quote=The '90s was a formative time for American rave culture, as the scene was already booming in the UK. But it was really the summer of 1993, at a club called the Edge, where a series of underground music events...}}{{cite interview |last=Milo |first=Christopher |subject-link=Electronic Music |interviewer=Joshua Glazer|title=Ep. 030 - DJ Three. Sasha at the Beacham Theatre (1994)] YouTube video | video4 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uOuSYGy96sc Clubbers leaving after patron collapsed (1994)] YouTube video{{collapsed infobox section end}} }} ====End of the Late Night and Live Entertainment eras==== Inside "Late Night" at the Beacham was always very dark and the auditorium was absolutely filthy. In contrast, initially the scene's "[[Energy (esotericism)|vibe]]" was pure and drugs such as [[MDMA]] that were available were relatively unadulterated. As time went on, the beloved Beacham was [[Beautification|beautified]] and remodeled into Dekko's. While the Beacham itself was cleaned up, the overall "vibe" of Orlando's scene seemed to darken somewhat just as the quality of [[club drugs]] that were still available during that time became tainted. During the summer of 1994, at a "Late Night" event featuring a [[guest appearance]] DJ Sasha, two female revelers who were attending a Reunion event at the Beacham Theatre collapsed just before sunrise. The women were carried outside to Orange Avenue in front of Dekko's where [[CPR]] was administered by an [[Orlando Police Department]] officer and [[paramedics]] were dispatched. Tragically, one of the young women [[death|expired]]. ''The Orlando Sentinel'' reported the May 1, 1994, passing of 20-year old Teresa Schwartz and that the other young woman was briefly in critical condition.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-05-02/news/9405020286_1_lake-mary-downtown-nightclub-orlando |title=2 Women Fall Ill At Club In Orlando - 1 Is Dead |author= |date=May 2, 1994 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 8, 2016 |quote=A 20-year-old Melbourne woman died and an 18-year-old Lake Mary woman is in critical condition after both collapsed from what Orlando police think were drug overdoses at a downtown nightclub Sunday morning.}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1995-06-18/news/9506150696_1_mdma-ecstasy-downtown-orlando |title=Drugs: Facing Agony Of Ecstasy |last1= Leithauser|first1=Tom |date=June 18, 1995 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 10, 2016 |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-07-06/news/9407060231_1_drug-overdose-schwartz-apparent-drug |title=Woman Dies Of Apparent Drug Overdose, Police Say |author= |date=July 6, 1994 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher= The Orlando Sentinel|access-date=July 29, 2016 |quote=In the earlier death, 20-year-old Teresa Schwartz of Melbourne collapsed May 1 outside of Dekko's Night Club on Orange Avenue downtown. Her purse contained canisters of nitrous oxide, a widely available anesthetic gas. The exact cause of Schwartz's death won't be known until laboratory tests are completed.}}{{cite book|author=Simon Reynolds|title=Generation Ecstasy: Into the World of Techno and Rave Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWf4J6yn9zAC&pg=PA315|date= June 19, 2013 |publisher= Routledge |isbn=978-1-136-78316-6|pages=315–}}{{cite book|author=Simon Reynolds|title=Energy Flash: A Journey Through Rave Music and Dance Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o5wGKnxoTAwC|date=March 1, 2012|publisher=Counterpoint LLC|isbn=978-1-59376-477-7}} However, she promptly recovered. [[Substance abuse]], related [[cardiac arrhythmia]], or [[hyperthermia]] was the [[theory|suspected]] [[Preventable causes of death|cause of death]]. The incident along with those at other venues in Orlando, shocked the underground dance club scene in Central Florida and were followed by a dramatic decrease in attendance. "Late Night's" organizers made the responsible decision to end Reunion at Dekko's after their pleas for young club-goers to practice [[moderation]] were ignored. The Dekko's concept was sold to a competitor in the following months. [[File:AAHZ Reunion.jpg|thumb|150px|left|2016 AAHZ Reunion]] On Saturday nights during 1995 "Late Night" briefly resumed in The Club at [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company|Firestone]] with DJ Robby Clark Kimball Collins, Dave Cannalte, StaceBass and friends. However, the City of Orlando subsequently created a "Rave Review Task Force" in 1997 and later passed a [[local ordinance]] that contributed to Florida's crackdown on after-hours nightclubs.{{cite web |url= http://www.orlandoweekly.com/orlando/a-short-history-of-the-orlandos-relationship-with-the-club-scene/Content?oid=2460038 |title=A short history of Orlando's relationship with the club scene |author= |date= December 30, 2015 |website=orlandoweekly.com |publisher=The Orlando Weekly |access-date=August 20, 2016 |quote=1988: According to a 1988 story in Orlando Weekly, DJ Kimball Collins discovers an acid-house night happening at the old Beacham Theater in Orlando and before long, he morphs it into AAHZ, the legendary house-music dance party that attracts people from all over Florida and turns Orlando into an epicenter for club culture. 1992: AAHZ at the Beacham comes to an end, after struggling to compete with newer dance clubs, like the Abyss and Club Firestone. 1993: The Orange County Convention Center is home to a massive rave called Infinite, which would return to the venue for three consecutive years. 1993: DJ Kimball Collins introduces a new night called Reunion at a club called Dekko's. 1993: The Dust Brothers (later known as the Chemical Brothers) headline a massive rave at the Edge Nightclub in downtown Orlando, giving birth to an electronic dance music scene that would eventually sweep the nation. 1994: A female patron of a dance party called Reunion collapses and dies; Reunion is canceled for good three weeks later}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1997-04-04/news/9704031396_1_orlando-nightclubs-raves-downtown-orlando |title= Task Force Tackles Drug Use In Nightclubs|last1=Sherri |first1=Owens|date=April 4, 1997 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=''The Orlando Sentinel'' |access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=At least two potential solutions to the drug problems at Orlando's all-night parties emerged Thursday at the first meeting of the city's Rave Review Task Force...Orlando has the biggest rave scene in Florida}}{{cite web |url= http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19970910&slug=2559661 |title= All-Night Raves Banned By Orlando Ordinance -- Attempt To Diminish Drug Use Leads To Restrictions On City's Bars And Nightclubs|last1= Schneider |first1=Mike |date=September 10, 1997 |website=seattletimes.nwsource.com |publisher=''The Seattle Times'' |access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=On Monday, the Orlando City Council voted 5-2 to shut down the city's bars and nightclubs at 3 a.m.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1177/orlando-fla-cracks-down-on-all-night-raves/|title= Orlando, Fla. Cracks Down On All-Night Raves|last1=Nelson |first1= Chris |date=September 10, 1997|website=MTV.com |publisher=''MTV'' |access-date=August 5, 2016 |quote=On Monday, the Orlando general assembly upheld the state bill to axe raves, after-hour dance parties, voting to force venues that serve alcohol to shut their doors at 3 a.m., one hour after last call.}} Central Florida's crackdown led to the eventual passage of an "anti-rave" law in Florida that ultimately led to the signing of national [[Reducing Americans' Vulnerability to Ecstasy Act|Anti-Rave legislation]]. The Aahz Reunion Tour launched in 1998 and as of 2016, reunions of Aahz "Late Night" occur nearly biannually and are frequently held in the Beacham Theatre. "Late Night" reunions, however, now end promptly before 2:30 a.m. ====Night Club exclusive use era==== By 1992 the future looked brighter for the Beacham Theatre when Mike Berry, staff writer, for ''The Orlando Sentinel'' wrote that, "The Beacham Theatre is the latest testament to [[reincarnation]]." Concerts were no longer being held in the auditorium during this time period and the Beacham Theatre was used exclusively as night club through 2010. It was 1992 when Orlando [[Lawyer|Attorney]] Mark NeJame leased the Beacham Theatre with the option to match the purchase price of any prospective buyers. The Beacham underwent restoration at a cost of in excess of $1,000,000. NeJame then opened "'''Dekko's'''," a mainstream "high-energy dance club." "Dekko's" is an [[Amalgamation (names)|amalgam]] of [[Art Deco|Deco]] and [[Gekko]]. The "Dekko's" concept featured a rose-beige exterior with a newly [[Building restoration|restored]] [[Art Deco]] inspired facade with red [[neon lighting]]. Dekko's interior included extensive use of the color [[purple]] and a [[sushi]] bar in the balcony. The inclusion of a [[terrarium]] ([[vivarium]]) with live subtropical [[geckos]] was planned.{{cite news |last= Berry |first=Mike |date=October 14, 1992 |title=Another facade may soon grace historic Beacham: Beacham may get a Face Lift |url= |newspaper= The Orlando Sentinel|location=Orlando, FL |access-date=}} "Dekko's" was open from late 1992 until the "high-energy dance club" [[concept]] was bought out in 1994 by Bill Harmening who operated The Edge, a competing nightclub. "'''Zuma Beach Club'''" followed Dekko's and opened in 1994.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-01-28/news/9601250598_1_orlando-opera-opera-house-movie-houses |title= Early Entertainment Venues Evolved From Opera House To Movie Theaters|author= |date=January 28, 1996 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date= August 21, 2016|quote=...the former site of the county jail where hangings once were conducted - and built the Beacham Theater...Air conditioning was installed in the '30s...It later was home to Laser World; then to Moulin Orange, a Las Vegas-style cabaret that lasted four months in 1983-84; and then to Valentyne's Celebrity Dinner Theatre, which opened in 1987.}} The recently remodeled auditorium was gutted for the change. Redecoration was complete with [[fishing net]]s, galvanized [[watering trough]]s for beer, and [[warning signs]] for [[sharks]]. On February 22, 1995, NeJame entered a new [[partnership]] with George Maltezos, John SanFelippo and brother, Joseph SanFelippo. Zuma Beach was often described by NeJame as "the cheesiest club in America." ''Rolling Stone'' in 1997 described Zuma Beach as a "cheesy dive." Zuma Beach even hosted an [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] "hardcore" [[professional wrestling]] match on January 29, 2000.{{cite web |url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/ecw/results/2000a.html#012900 |title=ECW hardcore wrestling |author= |date=January–March 2000 |website=prowrestlinghistory.com |publisher=Pro Wrestiling History |access-date=November 22, 2016 |quote=January 29, 2000 in Orlando, FL; Zuma Beach Club drawing 800}} Mercifully, "Zuma Beach" closed its doors in late 2000.{{cite web |url= http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2000-06-09/entertainment/0006080412_1_beacham-nejame-zuma|title=Beacham Theatre May live Again |last1= Emmons|first1=M. F.|date= July 9, 2000 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 10, 2016 |quote=}} Finally, after yet another remodeling of the auditorium, "'''Tabu''' opened in 2001." Initially, Tabu was more of an upscale nightclub. [[Backstreet Boy]] [[Howie Dorough]], who performed his first musical at the Beacham as one of the [[Munchkins]] in the [[Lollipop Guild]] for a [[theatre production]] of ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1987 musical)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', was a design and talent acquisition advisor for Tabu. However, Tabu later became more [[mainstream]]. Tabu had a weekly lineup presentation that with the exception of hosting live music, was similar to the theater's current nightclub iteration.{{cite web |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-01-06/entertainment/os-bars-rail-010711-20110106_1_tabu-hip-hop-sanfelippo-and-george-maltezos |title=Tabu is now The Beacham |author= |date=January 6, 2011 |website=orlandosentinel.com |publisher=The Orlando Sentinel |access-date=August 10, 2016 |quote= John SanFelippo and George Maltezos, co-owners of Tabu ... have partnered with Gerard Mitchell and Michael McRaney, co-owners of The Social, in opening the newly named venue at 46 N. Orange Ave. The Social and The Beacham are next-door neighbors. Fans of Tabu need not fret because the weekend lineup will stay the same}} Tabu closed in late 2010 when Mark NeJame and Joseph SanFelippo left the partnership. ====Return of Live Entertainment==== [[File:Beacham logo 1.gif|thumb|115px|right|Beacham logo]] In 2011 leases for the Beacham Theatre were renewed by John SanFelippo and George Maltezos, along with Gerard Mitchell and Michael McRaney, who leased the adjacent unit. Their [[partnership]] is named 46/54 North Orange Ave, LLC, and both units are leased from building owners Margaret Casscells and Frank Hamby, of Beacham Theater, LLC. [[File:The Beacham logo.png|thumb|200px|left]] Since 2011 "'''The Beacham'''" nightclub has operated in partnership with "The Social," a smaller venue next door at 54 North Orange Avenue. The venues, are connected via a [[Passage (architecture)|passage]] and [[door]]. The Beacham features [[disc jockey]] entertainment and plays [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]], [[Top 40]], [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]], and [[Reggaeton]]." The Live Entertainment era currently continues on stages at both The Beacham and partner The Social. Prominent national and international musical acts perform with [[fidelity]] to the countless shows by numerous acts that have previously held performances in the Beacham Theatre from the mid-1970s through the early-1990s. ==Description== Beacham's Building is divided into seven rental units using wood frame, brick walls, different facades, and paint. The theater is the south-most unit. The two-story Beacham Theatre was constructed in 1921 in a simple 20th Century Commercial Style. The structure is constructed of [[reinforced concrete]] and [[brick]] with [[stucco]] out-surface. Utilization of wood in the construction was minimized. ===Historical=== The facade was decorated with multi-colored tile trim and impregnated with [[seashell]]. The first story originally contained two small storefronts, a [[boxoffice]], and lobby entrance to the theater as well the [[auditorium]], [[Stage (theatre)|stage]], dressing rooms, staff restrooms, and a [[green room]]. The second story of the theater contained [[Bathroom|restrooms]], windowed offices, a [[projection booth]], and [[balcony]] seating section as well as additional [[dressing room (theater)|dressing rooms]] accessible by a spiral staircase. Above the stage was the [[fly system]] and [[Catwalk (theater)|catwalk]]. === Modifications === In 1936 [[Art Deco]] styling with Mediterranean-style tile was added to the facade and extensive neon lighting was installed the on the entrance [[Overhang (architecture)|overhang]]. Inside, the theater was modernized to provide lighted stairs, air conditioning into the dressing rooms, an enlarged auditorium, and improved seating. Capacity was reduced to 1,051. To diminish [[echo (phenomenon)|echo]]es from the projectors and recorded sound equipment, the auditorium was carpeted with a floral pattern and the plaster walls were covered with an Ozite material.{{cite interview|last=Robinson|first=Wendall|subject-link=|interviewer=B.T. Sherwood|title=Interview of Wendall O. Robinson (projectionist)|url=|location=Orlando|date=February 5, 1982|access-date=}} Vernon Hunter oversaw the modernization. [[File:Beacham Theatre upstairs offices in 1991.jpg|thumb|170px|Beacham Theatre upstairs offices in March 1991.]] In 1954 the look of the theater was modernized once again with the removal of [[parapets]], [[cornices]], and windows. The marquee was replaced with a new [[Vitreous enamel|porcelain]] one. The lobby was enclosed with glass doors and the [[boxoffice]] was moved to the right side of the lobby exterior and rebuilt. An entirely new stucco sheeting was installed over the facade, a wide screen was installed, and new decorations and push-back seats were added with additional alterations to the floor plan and seating areas. Capacity was reduced to 650. In 1964 the [[proscenium]] was modified to accommodate the installation of [[Cinerama]] widescreen. A new projection room was constructed under the balcony to accommodate 70-mm projectors. By 1975 the theater was no longer being used as a feature cinema. For the 1976 opening of the Great Southern Music Hall, the theater's interior and stage were remodeled, the proscenium was rebuilt, balcony seating was added. The facade was repainted with Art Deco graphics and a large mural was painted on the back of the theater. Capacity was increased to 765. [[File:Beacham Theatre balcony restoration in 1991.jpg|thumb|180px|The balcony was remodeled in March 1991 revealing the theater's original 35 mm film projection port.]] The balcony was extended in 1981. In 1984 the theater cinema's 765 seats were removed and sold and the sloped auditorium floor was [[Terrace (stadium)|terraced]]. Buffet dinner tables for 400 and balcony tables for 100 were added. The [[Parts of a theatre#Backstage or offstage|backstage]] area was remodeled, and the balcony was restored back to its original shape. Exterior [[drainage]] was improved. The degraded ceiling plasterwork was repaired and repainted, the roof was replaced and wiring were upgraded in 1988. External air conditioning was being pumped in. By 1991 the balcony was renovated and re-extended and the [[70 mm film]] projection room under the balcony had been removed and the air conditioning repaired. Opera boxes were installed on the second floor of either side of the stage and the DJ booth was relocated shortly thereafter. [[File:Beacham Theatre restoration proposal.jpg|thumb|220px|left|Facade restoration proposal for the Beacham Theatre]] As the Beacham was renovated to become Dekkos's in 1992, it was discovered that the stucco sheeting that was installed during a modernization in 1954 could not be economically removed without severely damaging the original facade underneath. Restoration plans for the facade had to be modified. An arched molding was then added to the facade. A [[sunburst]] and red neon lighting was subsequently added. Following an effort to "bring back the [[aesthetics]] of the old Beacham Theatre," in 2000 owners restored the Beacham's ornate [[plaster]] ceiling moldings, [[facade]], and marquee. In addition, the sloping theater floor was made level and the stage was elevated. The original Beacham Theatre sign is awaiting [[Building restoration|restoration]] and is being stored on the roof. Around 2005, the facade was modified by removing a small semi-circular molding in front of the sunburst. The points of the [[sunburst]] were also removed leaving a large semi-circular molding and larger arch above it decorating the facade. [[File:Beacham Theatre facade in 2015.jpg|thumb|180px|Beacham Theatre's facade was in poor condition between 2014 and 2016.]] ====Recent Changes==== The balcony and upstairs areas were [[Renovation|remodeled]] in 2011 with a beautifully painted ceiling and the addition of two [[chandeliers]]. [[Public toilet|Restroom]]s were installed in place of the theater's original office area and [[35 mm film]] [[projection booth]]. The theater's ornate plaster ceilings are in a state of disrepair with the decorative ceiling concealed behind a black cloth barrier that can retain any pieces of plaster that might fall. During the summer months of 2016 the crumbling arched molding was removed from the facade. The facade was then repaired and repainted and new red and blue neon lighting was installed. Further restoration in the near future is in a discussion and planning stage. ==Notable performances == [[Vaudeville]] acts that have performed at the Beacham Theatre include the [[Ziegfeld Follies]], [[John Phillip Sousa]], [[W.C. Fields]], [[Irving Berlin]]'s ''[[Music Box Revue]]'', [[Frieda Hempel]], [[Theda Bara]], [[Irving Caesar]]'s ''The Greenwich Village Follies of 1922'', organist "Professor" Herman Siewert, [[Benjamin Franklin Keith|Keith's]] Vaudeville Company, [[ventriloquist]] [[List of vaudeville performers: L–Z|Marshall Montgomery]], [[Flo Ziegfeld]]'s ''[[Sally (musical)|Sally]]'', [[Gertrude Hoffmann (dancer)|Gertrude Hoffmann Dancers]], ''Artists and Models Super Revue of 1924'', The Cloverleaf Dancers, [[Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks|The Elks]] [[Minstrel show|Minstrels]], "Fay, Lane, & Barry;" "Fay Two Colleys;" and [[gymnasts]] The Kramer Brothers. [[Blues]] and [[Jazz]] legends [[Ray Charles]], [[B.B. King]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Johnny Sansone]], [[Delbert McClinton]], [[Leon Russell]], [[Edgar Winter]], [[Leo Kottke]], [[Roy Buchanan]], [[Dr. John]], [[Buckwheat Zydeco]], [[Maynard Ferguson]], [[Billy Cobham]], [[Gato Barbieri]], [[Ramsey Lewis]], [[Freddie Hubbard]], and [[Diane Schuur]] have performed at the Beacham Theatre. [[Classic rock]] era acts such as [[The Police]], [[The Pretenders]], [[Rick Derringer]], [[Pat Travers Band]], [[Al Stewart]], [[Dickey Betts]], [[Head East]], [[Sea Level (band)|Sea Level]], [[Utopia (American band)|Utopia]], [[Horslips]], [[New Riders of the Purple Sage]], [[Dave Brubeck]], [[Todd Rundgren]], Bill Warheit, [[Michael Hedges]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[José Feliciano]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[Root Boy Slim]], and the [[Ramones]] have performed at the Beacham.{{cite web |url=http://www.setlist.fm/venue/the-great-southern-music-hall-orlando-fl-usa-5bd73bc0.html |title=The Great Southern Music Hall Orlando Concert Setlists |author= |date= |website= setlist.fm |publisher=Setlist.fm |access-date=August 7, 2016 |quote=}} [[Heavy metal music|Metal]] acts such as [[Judas Priest]], [[Slayer]], [[Gwar]], [[Dark Angel (band)|Dark Angel]], [[7 Seconds (band)|7 seconds]], [[Overkill (band)|Overkill]], and [[Wolfsbane (band)|Wolfsbane]], and [[Death Angel]] have appeared at the Beacham. [[Reggae]] acts [[Pato Banton]], [[Toots Hibbert]], [[The Maytals]], [[Inner Circle (band)|Inner Circle]], [[The Wailers]], [[Aswad (band)|Aswad]], and [[Yellowman]] have also performed. In more recent years [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]], [[KMFDM]], [[Fugazi]], [[Revolting Cocks]], [[Devo]], [[Book of Love (band)|Book of Love]], [[Go Radio]], [[Tori Amos]], [[Soundgarden]], [[The Pixies]], [[Good Charlotte]], [[Pink (singer)|Pink]], [[Lush (band)|Lush]], [[David Byrne]], [[Fishbone]], [[The Cramps]], [[Flat Duo Jets]], [[L.A. Guns]], [[G. Love & Special Sauce]], and The [[Les Claypool|Claypool]] [[Sean Lennon|Lennon]] [[Monolith of Phobos|Delirium]] as well as notable DJ acts Razor and Guido, [[Carl Cox]], [[Sasha (Welsh DJ)|Sasha]], [[John Digweed]], [[Dave Seaman]] and Dynamix II and many others have played at the Beacham.{{cite web |url=http://www.clubplanet.com/Venues/201357/Orlando/THE-BEACHAM |title=The Beacham, Orlando Clubplanet nightlife directory |author= |date=2016 |website= clubplanet.com|publisher=Clubplanet |access-date=August 3, 2016 |quote=}} The Beacham website offers the following synopsis:{{cite web |url=http://www.beachamorlando.com/ |title=The Beacham |author= |date= 2013|website=beachamorlando.com |publisher=The Beacham |access-date=July 29, 2016 |quote=}}{{quote|text=Downtown's notorious venue has entertained Orlando for almost 100 years, with a diverse history from vaudeville, to cinema and epic concert events. This building has encountered countless celebrities and their greatest projects. In the last four decades, various superstars have graced this Orange Avenue venue's mammoth stage including but not limited to [[50 Cent]], [[Lauryn Hill]], [[Ice Cube]], [[2 Chainz]], [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]], [[Trina]], [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]], [[French Montana]], [[Meek Mill]], [[Rick Ross]], [[Waka Flocka Flame]], [[J. Cole]], [[Trick Daddy]], [[DJ Khaled]], and [[Flo Rida]]. Dance music's innovative DJs [[The Crystal Method]], [[Paul Oakenfold]], [[Benny Benassi]], [[Armin Van Buuren]], [[Tiesto]], [[Afrojack]], and [[David Guetta]] have also called this historic location home.|sign=|source=|Downtown's notorious venue has entertained Orlando for almost 100 years, with a diverse history from vaudeville, to cinema and epic concert events. This building has encountered countless celebrities and their greatest projects. In the last four decades, various superstars have graced this Orange Avenue venue's mammoth stage including but not limited to [[50 Cent]], [[Lauryn Hill]], [[Ice Cube]], [[2 Chainz]], [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]], [[Trina]], [[Juvenile (rapper)|Juvenile]], [[French Montana]], [[Meek Mill]], [[Rick Ross]], [[Waka Flocka Flame]], [[J. Cole]], [[Trick Daddy]], [[DJ Khaled]], and [[Flo Rida]]. Dance music's innovative DJs [[The Crystal Method]], [[Paul Oakenfold]], [[Benny Benassi]], [[Armin Van Buuren]], [[Tiesto]], [[Afrojack]], and [[David Guetta]] have also called this historic location home.}} [[Professional wrestler]]s [[Rob Van Dam]], [[Masato Tanaka]], [[Rhyno]], [[Super Crazy]], [[The Dupps]], [[Yoshihiro Tajiri]], [[Tommy Dreamer]], and [[Simon Diamond]] had a match in the Beacham Theatre. ==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|Biography|Discrimination|Film|Florida|History|Music|Theater}} *[[House Music]] *[[Psychedelic music]] *[[Rave]] *[[Rave music]] *[[Well'sbuilt Hotel]] ==External links== * [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/keyword/beacham Beacham Theatre article collection archive] of [[The Orlando Sentinel]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:Former cinemas in the United States]] [[Category:Theatres in Florida]] [[Category:History of Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:Entertainment venues in Florida]] [[Category:Music venues in Florida]] [[Category:Music venues in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:20th century in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:Electronic music]] [[Category:Psychedelia]] [[Category:Subcultures]] [[Category:Civil rights and liberties]]
